Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

POR.DRECONTENT:
As part of the Alliances for Graduate Education and the Professoriate (AGEP) program, our project's major goal was to increase significantly the number of domestic (U.S. citizen and U.S. permanent resident) students pursuing advanced study, earning doctoral degrees in the sciences, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM), with special emphasis on those population groups underrepresented in these fields (i.e., African Americans, Hispanics, American Indians, Alaska Natives, Native Hawaiians or other Pacific Islanders), and ultimately increase the number of underrepresented minorities (URMs) who will enter the professoriate in specified STEM disciplines. In seeking to achieve these goals our MGE@MSA AGEP alliance engaged in comprehensive institutional cultural changes intended to lead to sustained increases in the achievement of earned STEM doctoral degrees at levels significantly exceeding the historic performance. The specific objectives of the our project have been to (1) to develop and implement innovative models for recruiting, mentoring, and retaining URM students in STEM doctoral programs, and (2) to develop effective strategies for identifying and supporting URMs who want to pursue academic careers.

Based on the tremendous success of our MGE@MSA AGEP Phase I alliance that was funded in part by a NSF cooperative agreement since October 1999, Phase II, beginning in March 2005, greatly expanded our existing highly successful alliance program activities on behalf of URMs in STEM. Alliance activities continued to include doctoral student recruitment, student research conferences, faculty doctoral student mentoring, student travel, faculty documentation of student academic progress, and peer/faculty networking initiatives, as well as now also including, for the first time, postdoctoral and junior faculty workshops, networking, mentorship, and opportunities that will lead to achievement of a high quality of the research, teaching, and service that, in turn, will directly and expeditiously ultimately lead to tenure and promotion for an increasing number of URM STEM researchers. We continued to work very closely with our companion and partner LSAMP alliance, WAESO (Western Alliance to Expand Student Opportunities), including nine cohorts of WAESO Bridge to the Doctorate Students.

The intellectual merit of our alliance has been to draw upon and expand our participating institutions’ large existing communities of URM STEM scholar/researcher/teacher/mentors and student apprentice/scholar/researcher/ teacher/protégés working collaboratively to further structure and sustain a research-based “hot house” environment to create widespread regional systemic change with dramatically positive national implications and repercussions. The broader impacts of our alliance have been to achieve and sustain a level of admission, development, graduation, placement, promotion, and tenure of doctoral, post-doctoral, junior faculty, and senior faculty URM STEM scholars more closely in proportion to the diversity of our society as a whole. We have strong reason to believe that our MGE@MSA AGEP alliance is a national model for the strengthening and diversification of STEM faculty to ensure that the U.S. will continue to lead the world in research and technology despite the increasingly intense global competition of the 21st century.

For example:

  • By the tenth and final year of Phase II our MGE@MSA AGEP alliance we had an alliance yearly total of 94 underrepresented STEM doctoral graduations, an increase of 6% from the previous year. Our annual rate is now 409% of the original Phase I Baseline.
  • In total, MGE@MSA participating underrepresented STEM doctoral students published at least 385 research articles in peer- reviewed STEM academic journals.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: As part of the Alliances for Graduate Education and the Professoriate (AGEP) program, our project's major goal was to increase significantly the number of domestic (U.S. citizen and U.S. permanent resident) students pursuing advanced study, earning doctoral degrees in the sciences, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM), with special emphasis on those population groups underrepresented in these fields (i.e., African Americans, Hispanics, American Indians, Alaska Natives, Native Hawaiians or other Pacific Islanders), and ultimately increase the number of underrepresented minorities (URMs) who will enter the professoriate in specified STEM disciplines. In seeking to achieve these goals our MGE@MSA AGEP alliance engaged in comprehensive institutional cultural changes intended to lead to sustained increases in the achievement of earned STEM doctoral degrees at levels significantly exceeding the historic performance. The specific objectives of the our project have been to (1) to develop and implement innovative models for recruiting, mentoring, and retaining URM students in STEM doctoral programs, and (2) to develop effective strategies for identifying and supporting URMs who want to pursue academic careers. Based on the tremendous success of our MGE@MSA AGEP Phase I alliance that was funded in part by a NSF cooperative agreement since October 1999, Phase II, beginning in March 2005, greatly expanded our existing highly successful alliance program activities on behalf of URMs in STEM. Alliance activities continued to include doctoral student recruitment, student research conferences, faculty doctoral student mentoring, student travel, faculty documentation of student academic progress, and peer/faculty networking initiatives, as well as now also including, for the first time, postdoctoral and junior faculty workshops, networking, mentorship, and opportunities that will lead to achievement of a high quality of the research, teaching, and service that, in turn, will directly and expeditiously ultimately lead to tenure and promotion for an increasing number of URM STEM researchers. We continued to work very closely with our companion and partner LSAMP alliance, WAESO (Western Alliance to Expand Student Opportunities), including nine cohorts of WAESO Bridge to the Doctorate Students. The intellectual merit of our alliance has been to draw upon and expand our participating institutionsÃ† large existing communities of URM STEM scholar/researcher/teacher/mentors and student apprentice/scholar/researcher/ teacher/protégés working collaboratively to further structure and sustain a research-based "hot house" environment to create widespread regional systemic change with dramatically positive national implications and repercussions. The broader impacts of our alliance have been to achieve and sustain a level of admission, development, graduation, placement, promotion, and tenure of doctoral, post-doctoral, junior faculty, and senior faculty URM STEM scholars more closely in proportion to the diversity of our society as a whole. We have strong reason to believe that our MGE@MSA AGEP alliance is a national model for the strengthening and diversification of STEM faculty to ensure that the U.S. will continue to lead the world in research and technology despite the increasingly intense global competition of the 21st century. For example: By the tenth and final year of Phase II our MGE@MSA AGEP alliance we had an alliance yearly total of 94 underrepresented STEM doctoral graduations, an increase of 6% from the previous year. Our annual rate is now 409% of the original Phase I Baseline. In total, MGE@MSA participating underrepresented STEM doctoral students published at least 385 research articles in peer- reviewed STEM academic journals.
